Black strikes at the white centre.
White closes the position
Black attacks white's centre
White develops
Black exchanges. I regard this as a mistake as it relieves pressure on the white centre. If white were ever to play 0-0-0 it would be hard for black to open up files against the white king.
So I take back.
I'm not sure this is best, why not Nh5 and f5 immediately?
So I develop
The usual knight move
I develop my queen
He develops his knight

After a long thought, I decide to castle queenside, which is what I often do in this sort of position. My thinking is this - if I castle kingside he has a ready-made attack with f5-f4, g5-g4-g3 etc. If he tries to attack my king on the queenside, he is going to find it hard to open uip the a or the b file. There are two plans I can follow - either move my king to b1, and try and take over the c file, or to launch an attack on the kingisde. However afterwards I found that castling kingside is more common in this position. What do you think dear reader, which side would you castle on?
So his "attack" starts
I tuck my king away. I am not afraid of 13...b4 14 Na4 as he can't then make much progress on the queenside.

Threatening b4 now. I was surprised that this position is in the Gameknot opening database. There are two games. Both times white played a3 here. But I thought a3 would just help black open up lines on the queenside. I decided to give my knight the d1 square and played...
Also with a view to taking over the c file sometime.
So he develops. I considered Nxb5 here, but it is refuted by Qxd2 16. Bxd2 axb5 17. Rc7 Nc5, attacking Bd3, so I played
